body: Can you explain what you're trying to do please?

Tested with 3.2.2 and it returns false. PSR-7 says `getParsedBody()` says return value should be `null|array|object`. Seems behaviour is wrong at the moment. ``` php $app->post("/test", function ($request, $response, $args) { var_dump($request->getParsedBody()); }); ``` ``` %curl --include --request POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/test HTTP/1.1 200 OK Host: 127.0.0.1:8080 Connection: close X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.17 Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Content-Length: 103 
boolean false
```

What content-type would that request be @tuupola ?

I am guessing there's a logic error in here.

https://github.com/slimphp/Slim/blob/3.x/Slim/Http/Request.php#L972-L982

We should have a unit test for this as well.

_edit_
We could add a guard around line 980,

``` php
if ($parsedBody === false) {
    $parsedBody = [];
}
```
@p-golovin  The if can't have an else that returns null, then nothing would get parsed ;)

issue.title: Ensure getParsedBody() return null if body is not parsed

repository.name: Slim
repository.description: Slim is a PHP micro framework that helps you quickly write simple yet powerful web applications and APIs.

issue.body:
PSR-7 states that getParsedBody() must return null, an array or an object. If we can't parse the body as there's no media type parser available, then return null.

Fixes #1807

body: I would appreciate review and test of #1808 to see if this solves the problem.

issue.title: RuntimeException thrown when submitting invalid XML

repository.name: Slim
repository.description: Slim is a PHP micro framework that helps you quickly write simple yet powerful web applications and APIs.

issue.body:
Slim seems to throw a RuntimeException when submitting invalid XML data.

The xml media parser in Request.php, which uses simplexml_load_string to parse the request body, returns false when it's unable to validate the xml, and thereupon, an exception is thrown if the media parser doesn't return an array, an object or a null value.

Is this behaviour by design, or is it a bug? It seems a bit strange to me to stop the processing abruptly at this early point, before reaching a route. Wouldn't it be better to return a null value, and to let the routes - or middleware - decide what to do no valid data is passed to them?

May be related to issue #1807.
